channel.title: Latest PHMSA Hazardous Materials Incident Reports, for OH
channel.description: The latest Form 5800.1 hazardous material reports submitted to the Department of Transportation and posted online by the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration, for OH

item.title: Report X-2024080732
item.description:
Report X-2024080732

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-14T15:13:37+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-08-04
  • City: COLUMBUS
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: RESPONDER WAS CALLED TO THE IRREG LINE FOR A HAZMAT LEAKER FOUND ON A CART. USING THE DECISION TREE, FLAMMABLE LIQUID RESPONSE SHEET AND ALL APLICABLE PPE, THE PACKAGE WAS REMOVED TO A LINED SPILL TUB AND TRANSPORTED TO PSC AREA FOR FURTHRT PROCESSING.

item.title: Report E-2024080264
item.description:
Report E-2024080264

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-14T15:13:37+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-26
  • City: FINDLAY
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On July 26, 2024, one (1) tote of organic peroxide was damaged in a load shift and released approximately one (1) gallon of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Thin Line Environmental (TLE) to remediate the impacted site. Crews deployed granular absorbent to the trailer floor and worked them in with hand tools. All organic peroxide impacted material was collected and containerized in one (1) 35-gallon drum for disposal.

item.title: Report E-2024080186
item.description:
Report E-2024080186

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-12T15:14:41+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-31
  • City: HUBER HEIGHTS
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: DAYTON FREIGHT LINES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On July 31, 2024, at 0812 ET, Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) was contacted by Dayton Freight Lines personnel in Huber Heights, Ohio regarding the release of CS-309â„¢ OTC (UN1866, 3, II). Terminal personnel reported that 6 ounces were release from (1) 5-gallon metal pail and impacted the trailer floor. Terminal personnel were able to clean the release with oil dri absorbents. All waste was placed in (1) 5-gallon DF and staged onsite pending disposal.

The investigation revealed that the container was punctured by a protruding nail head in the skid. The released material was neutralized and collected for proper disposal.

item.title: Report E-2024080078
item.description:
Report E-2024080078

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-08T15:13:41+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-08-01
  • City: Canton
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: Wheeling and Lake Erie Railway
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: at 0100 hrs. while inspecting their train, the WLE Gambrinus Yard train crew, noticed tank car TILX 305022 at Gambrinus Yard leaking vapor from the top of the car. They notified the WLE Gambrinus Yardmaster who then contacted myself, John Vergis, Hazardous Materials Officer for the WLE. When I arrived, I could her the car leaking vapor from on top the car. The leak was substantial, but just vapor, no liquid. I climbed the car and removed seal # 0672272 from the protective housing lid. I investigated and found no leak inside the protective housing. Upon further investigation, it was concluded that the leak was coming from the gasket connection between the pressure plate and the tank car nozzle. The pressure plate stud bolts appeared to be tight. There was no way to stop the leak. The leak was coming from the left side of the housing. I called CHEMTREC at 0127 hrs. to make a report and have them contact Marathon Petroleum in order to give me assistance. Jennifer Johnson, the emergency contact from Marathon called me at 0158 to inquire about the report. The CHEMTREC Report number was 2024080100010. I told her what was going on and that I would be calling 911 to request the Stark County HAZMAT Team. I also told her that I would be calling Enviroserve out of North Canton, Ohio to come out and do an emergency transfer of the car since that was the only way we could stop it from leaking. She agreed and had me make the calls. I called 911 at 0210 hrs. I called the Timken Steel Security folks to have them stop all traffic on their access road that parralels the location of the incident, so that they would be no chance for ignition from any of their equipment. I called Enviroserve at 0219 hrs. and briefed them on the situation and told them we needed and emergency transfer and then a flaring and purging of the car afterwards. I called the Stark County Spill Report Line at 0234 hrs. to report the incident. After we got the HAZMAT Team out and started doing air monitoring, I called to make a report with the Ohio EPA at 0505 just as a courtesy to report the vapor release. We had 7 area rays set up for air monitoring and discovered that the vapors were going straight up and not really concentrating around the car or anywhere else at ground level. No evacuations were required since the yard itself is isolated. We started to Transload the car at about 0800 hrs. We started to flare the car of its residual vapors at about 1430 hrs. and finished at 2230 hrs. The car was labeled with Do Not Load and Home Shop Stickers and was stenciled â€œCleanedâ€.

item.title: Report E-2024080079
item.description:
Report E-2024080079

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-08T15:13:41+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-26
  • City: MONROE
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: CARRIER IS AN INDIVIDUAL
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: At 3:32 pm on Friday, July 26, 2024, During the loading process the driver failed to secure his manway before departure. The driver, after leaving Worthington Monroe, was contacted by PVS Dispatch and subsequently stopped on the side of the I-75 freeway, at the north end of the I-275 loop in Cincinnati, to tighten the bolts on the transport vehicle. Hepaco Project Manager: Bill Swope, (463) 253-5405 Bill Swope reported that the spill on the intersection of Lawton and interstate 62 amounted to approximately 3 gallons. Hepaco, a professional environmental and emergency response company, was engaged to handle the spill. Bryan Martin, Hepaco VP, and Bill Swope, the project manager, coordinated the cleanup operations. Hepaco was dispatched to clean the spill with the supervision of the Ohio EPA, Ohio EPA: Trevor Irwin, (614) 886-2484 The prompt and coordinated response by the Worthington Monroe team, in conjunction with Hepaco and the Ohio EPA, successfully mitigated the effects of the ferrous chloride spill. Through immediate action, effective communication, and thorough cleanup efforts, the environmental and health impacts of the spill were minimized.

item.title: Report E-2024080109
item.description:
Report E-2024080109

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-08T15:13:41+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-03
  • City: LORDSTOWN
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: It was reported that due to a nail puncture from the skid, approximately .25 gallon of Nexthane 9500 DTM Urethane (hazardous - UN1263) was released. The caller stated that the released product was contained to the trailer floor. ERTS reviewed the SDS with the caller and they felt comfortable cleaning the release donning the proper PPE per SDS. The released product, damaged pail, and oil-dri will be placed into a 20 gallon metal drum and staged in OS&D. There were no drains, soils or waterways reported to have been impacted by the release.
